questions.question_text: A technician is running new Cat 5e cables to a server room. Which of the following tools should the technician use to terminate the cables at the patch panel?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The correct tool to terminate the cables at the patch panel would be a Punchdown tool. The Punchdown tool is specifically designed for terminating Ethernet cables onto a patch panel or keystone jack. It allows the technician to push the individual wires into the appropriate slots on the patch panel, ensuring proper connections and secure termination.
A cable crimper is used to attach connectors to the ends of cables, but it is not suitable for terminating cables at a patch panel.

Selected Answer: D
Based on my response to IanB2621 below, I've gotta go with D - Punchdown Block.

Selected Answer: D
Punchdown tool

A punch down tool, which can also be named an RJ45 punch down tool, or Krone tool, is a hand tool widely used to terminate the Ethernet cables by inserting the cable wires into the insulation-displacement connectors (IDC) on the punch down blocks, patch panels, keystone modules, and surface mount of boxes.

A punch down tool, which can also be named an RJ45 punch down tool, or Krone tool, is a hand tool widely used to terminate the Ethernet cables by inserting the cable wires into the insulation-displacement connectors (IDC) on the punch down blocks, patch panels, keystone modules, and surface mount of boxes.

Selected Answer: B
Definitely Cable crimpers

questions.question_text:
A disaster recovery team needs a solution that would best meet the following requirements:

• The server infrastructure has been pre-installed
• The fail-over location offers basic life support.
• The fail-over location provides basic network connectivity.
• Minimizing cost is preferred over quicker business recovery times
• The expected time for services to be fully operational is days.

Which of the following sites would meet the requirements?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
A warm site is a scaled-down version of a hot site. The recovery site is often only configured with power, phone, and network jacks. It may have computers and other resources, but they are not configured and ready to go.
- You bring the hardware, software, data
- A second site in the event of a disaster
- Doesn’t mirror all live data

Selected Answer: C
This is 100% C.
There is basic life support already there.
Cold would be a site only, no gear.
Hot would be ready at a moments notice.

This is 100% warm

• Minimizing cost is preferred over quicker business recovery times
I think it's A. If it wasn't listed I'll go with C.

Selected Answer: C
A cold site is literally just physical space with electricity and *maybe* air conditioning. The obvious answer is warm site.

Selected Answer: C
It's C, Warm Site

From Jason Dion about Cold Sites:
"An available building that does not have any hardware or software in
place or configured
▪ While recovery is possible, it is going to be slow and time-consuming"

And about Warm Sites: 
"An available building that already contains a lot of the equipment
▪ Restoral time is between 24 hours and seven days"

Selected Answer: A
A cold site is a disaster recovery solution where the server infrastructure has been pre-installed but is not operational. The fail-over location provides basic network connectivity and basic life support, but no active servers or applications. In a cold site, the customer's equipment and systems need to be brought in, installed, and configured before they can be made operational. This type of site is preferred when cost minimization is a priority over quicker business recovery times, and the expected time for services to be fully operational is days.

Selected Answer: C
Based on the requirements listed, a disaster recovery team that needs a solution that prioritizes minimizing costs and expects services to be fully operational within days, while having basic network connectivity and basic life support at the fail-over location, would be best served by a warm site.

Selected Answer: C
There is a basic network connection so it has to be C in my opinion.

Selected Answer: C
I believe it's C not A

Selected Answer: D
D is the only one that makes sense. The termination point is loose and the cable has already been replaced so we can safely assume that the cable is not what we should be focusing on.
Fix the termination point and you're all set no?

Also note its the termination point that is loose, so C would not make sense as it doesn't say the connector is loose.

Selected Answer: A
Patch cable has already been replaced so it can't be D

Selected Answer: D
Although you would do some of these things, CompTIA really wants their test takers to think/do the thing that would be the most logical option to do FIRST. And/or the least invasive method FIRST.

choices.A: Use a tone generator to trace the cable
choices.C: Use a cable crimper to replace the RJ45 connector on the patch cable
choices.B: Use a multimeter to determine if PoE is available on the switchport
choices.D: Use a punchdown tool to reseat the copper in the wall jack

questions.question_text:
A technician troubleshoots a computer that has intermittent network connectivity and notices the termination point is loose. The technician also observes that the patch cable has already been replaced.

Which of the following should the technician do NEXT?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Mean Time to Repair (MTTR) is an important failure metric that measures the time it takes to troubleshoot and fix failed equipment or systems.

Selected Answer: B
B. MTTR (Mean Time To Repair)

Selected Answer: B
B. MTTR (Mean Time To Repair) is the most likely metric associated with the requirement of repairing the core network infrastructure in less than 60 minutes if any major part fails. MTTR measures the average time taken to repair a failed component or system and restore it to normal operation.

Selected Answer: A
Management team set the target. This is the RTO.

If RTO was also a choice it would have been difficult. Otherwise it is MTTR
RTO is max allowed
MTTR is what is average taken. So you choose based on RTO

Selected Answer: B
MTTR (mean time to recovery or mean time to restore) is the average time it takes to recover from a product or system failure. This includes the full time of the outage—from the time the system or product fails to the time that it becomes fully operational again.
b is the right one

questions.question_text: A company wants to invest in new hardware for the core network infrastructure. The management team requires that the infrastructure be capable of being repaired in less than 60 minutes if any major part fails. Which of the following metrics is MOST likely associated with this requirement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
A. Session - Layer 5
B. Frame - Layer 2
C. Firewall - Layer 3
D. Switch - Layer 2
E. Packet - Layer 3
F. Router - Layer 3

Selected Answer: BD
Frame and Switch are layer 2

Selected Answer: BD
B. Frame: Frames are the units of data at the data link layer. They encapsulate packets and include control information such as MAC addresses and error detection codes.
D. Switch: Switches operate at the data link layer and make forwarding decisions based on MAC addresses.

The devices and encapsulations found at the data link layer are:

B. Frame
D. Switch

questions.question_text: Which of the following devices and encapsulations are found at the data link layer? (Choose two.)
